nodes.title: Breaking News: New York passed a bill allowing noncitizens who are legally in the country to vote in local elections, becoming the largest U.S. city to do so. https://t.co/PoDiftizHg
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Prolonged grief disorder has been added to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, as experts predict a wave of severe bereavement because of the pandemic. It affects around 7% of those in mourning, preliminary studies suggest. https://t.co/7mnEm5SQfw https://t.co/Y72Ld6FrMg
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Breaking News: Starbucks workers at a store in Buffalo voted to unionize, making it the only company-owned store in the U.S. with a union. Votes at two other Buffalo-area stores will be counted later on Thursday. https://t.co/cjMYJHpuwc
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Josh Duggar, a onetime star of the TLC reality show "19 Kids and Counting," was convicted on Thursday on federal charges of downloading child sexual abuse imagery. He faces a maximum penalty of 40 years in prison and $500,000 in fines. https://t.co/3Jqj2EBvXk
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: President Biden unveiled a plan on Wednesday to make the federal government carbon neutral by 2050, ordering federal agencies to buy electric vehicles, to power facilities with wind, solar and nuclear energy, and to use sustainable building materials. https://t.co/piSpwkMtJ9 https://t.co/0NLNXkVCkt

nodes.title:
The assault of a French soccer player made headlines, with masked men, a metal bar and a teammate arrested.

But as details emerge about infidelity, accusations against other players and reports of menacing phone calls, no one is sure what to believe.
https://t.co/MPTEgWidEw
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: A 50-foot-tall Christmas tree outside the Fox News headquarters in New York City went up in flames. One man has been arrested, the police said. https://t.co/dYeIAvMA5A
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
When Angela Merkel became chancellor 16 years ago, George W. Bush was in the White House and Tony Blair was prime minister of Britain. There was no Twitter and no iPhone.

Here is a look back at pictures from her time at the helm.
https://t.co/FdBHqMDCPI

nodes.title: A book by Billie Eilish cost her publisher well over $1 million. But it sold only about 64,000 hardcover copies since it came out in May, highlighting the difficulty in predicting how well a book will sell. https://t.co/a3XGSx7XbH
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
A dominant era of German politics is ending today as Angela Merkel hands over the chancellery to Olaf Scholz, a Social Democrat with ambitions to revive progressive politics across Europe.

Follow live updates. https://t.co/Jv8lOvchGq
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: As manatee deaths spike and Florida rescue centers fill up with malnourished manatees, federal and state wildlife officials are taking an unprecedented step: They will provide food for hundreds of manatees in an urgent effort to get them through the winter.https://t.co/F39H7tODNA
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Ghislaine Maxwell has called the Metropolitan Detention Center "a living hell," but the judge overseeing her trial on sex trafficking and conspiracy charges has denied bail her four times, saying Maxwell poses "a substantial actual risk of flight." https://t.co/F0BdgOlHLi
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Saule Omarova, a Cornell Law professor whom President Biden picked for a key banking regulator job, is withdrawing from consideration for the post. Bank lobbyists and Republicans painted her as a communist because she was born in the Soviet Union. https://t.co/90ShBjM5WX
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: The U.S. surgeon general warned on Tuesday that young people are facing "devastating" mental health effects as a result of the challenges experienced by their generation, including the pandemic. https://t.co/ZLXK5YzIAN https://t.co/MU3O4fwuIJ

Lee statue, which was the focus of a deadly white nationalist rally in 2017, will be donated to an African American heritage center that plans to melt it down and create "art that will reflect racial justice and inclusion." https://t.co/vhDc43INJr https://t.co/lgj8mSlkQO

nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Female doctors make $2 million less over a 40-year career than their male counterparts, new research estimates. More men become surgeons and women have been shown to spend more time with their patients, leading to fewer services that can be billed for. https://t.co/q8ApaGYheI
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Chile became the 31st nation to legalize same-sex marriage on Tuesday, a landmark victory for gay rights activists that underscores how profoundly the countryâ€™s politics and society have shifted in the past decade. https://t.co/MCMiBI19SV

nodes.title: Drake's withdrawal from the 2022 Grammy Awards is the latest complication for the Recording Academy, which has struggled to prevent an exodus among artists who have complained about a poor win record for Black artists in the most prestigious categories. https://t.co/ztoFMfyX4n https://t.co/T5CzU9WRrf
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Michael Steinhardt, the billionaire hedge fund pioneer and one of New York's most prolific antiquities collectors, has surrendered 180 stolen objects valued at $70 million and been barred for life from acquiring any other relics, officials said Monday. https://t.co/Kgt2K8LkVc
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: As Elon Musk pushed his vision for self-driving cars at Tesla, he overrode safety concerns and may have misled drivers, former employees say. https://t.co/aNUJCIFmWQ
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
A court in Myanmar is expected to deliver the first verdicts against the countryâ€™s ousted civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. She is facing a series of rulings that could keep her locked up for the rest of her life.

Follow live updates. https://t.co/whyi8BbmrP
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Insufficient sleep can have widespread damaging effects on physical and mental health, including increased risk of developing heart disease, high blood pressure, stroke and Type 2 diabetes, a growing body of evidence suggests. https://t.co/7t4kkTu9K5
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Breaking News: The Justice Department sued Texas on Monday over the state's plan to redraw its voting districts, saying the new map would discriminate against Black and Latino voters, essentially making their votes count for less than fellow citizens'. https://t.co/YIb0lbjnH9
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
New York City will implement a sweeping vaccine mandate for all private employers that will take effect Dec. 27, Mayor Bill de Blasio said, calling it the first mandate of its kind in the U.S.
https://t.co/JtIEFLEFg7 https://t.co/4ihCNclIov

nodes.title: Officials and tribal entities agreed that 900 bison from Yellowstone National Park will be slaughtered, shot by hunters or relocated to address overgrazing. The bison have been roaming into Montana, where farmers fear they could spread disease to cattle. https://t.co/7OKrAFmS6q
